 It's not that "life survives because life survives".
 
 Take the environment: everything within it is destroyed with time. New things appear, and also soon disappear. Until one new thing appears that multiplies itself. As it multiplies, it continues to exist, unlike the others.
 
 Compare it to a fire: it's simply a chemical reaction. As long as there is fuel, it will burn. It will grow into a great firestorm, forming a self sustaining cycle, but in the end, it will run out - when it runs out of fuel.
 
 I imagine life as a more complex form of fire. At core, a simple chemical process replicating itself. Now, as it goes on, it grows more and more complex, and the better it gets at surviving, the better the chances are that it will manage to survive. In this way, starting from a simple chemical reaction, we come to the modern ecosystem.
 
 It's not that "life wants to live". It's more that "life is living".

 Let me preface my answer with another question:
 
 If it's possible for organisms to behave in manners which vary in their contribution to the organism's survival, which behaviours are going to survive best over long periods of time?
 
 The point is, once you appreciate a particular characteristic endures purely on its own merits, the question of why that characteristic arose transmutes into the simpler one of how. You don't need to find an answer laden with intent.
 
 It's also not as simple as 'desiring' ones own survival. There's no such thing as one human being - much of our success depends upon the societal structures we inherit and pass down along with our genes. While some people may find that they are selfish in their survival instincts, others may find they are more committed to the survival of the community or society of which they are a part. Both attitudes probably have value, since one may succeed when the other fails and permit at least some of the accumulated genetic/societal payload to survive.

let me backtrack a bit to a sort of prelogue of my question. i'm working on writing articles about motivation, but rather than approach it from the emotional level like all other motivational material does, i'm trying to dig beneath this to our most fundamental levels of motivation. our instincts for survival, or more accurately, to avoid discomfort, are at the deepest and most hardwired levels, as far as i can tell. 
 
 from maslow's hierarchy of needs, the base level of needs are those necessary for physical survival, and are essential. they are also inate and are almost impossible to alter. beyond that are emotional needs from security to self-esteem and altruism. 
 
 while the motivation for physical survival is about the same among humans, we greatly differ in how motivated we are to meet our emotional, social and psychological needs.
 
 i'm thinking that if there is a way to tie our other needs to our physical needs so strongly that our motivation to succeed is directly associated with our motivation to survive, then we wouldn't even have to think about success, we would be reflexively and subconsciously impelled towards success.
 
 science does an excellent job of explaining HOW, but a poor job at explaining WHY. it it also the main cause for the rift between science and religion, but thats another discussion entirely. in asking "why does life want to live?", i made it a philosophical question, rather than "how does life want to live?" i'm not trying to investigate the mechanisms or processes that allow usto survive, but rather the abstract motivational sources that fuel these processes, if that makes any sense
 
 theres a whole bunch of stuff on how paradigms, beliefs and habits interrelate in response to how we are motivated that i'll probably want to get into later, but for now, lets bear in mind that its more of a "soft science" question that calls for inference and theories.

 its interesting that living things are hardwired to survive. every organ in our bodies are designed with the mechanism to detect threats to our survival and the capability to respond by immediately changing so that we survive the threat. this is our nervous system. whenever we have a need, this is a threat to our survival, and we detect this threat by feeling discomfort. any form of discomfort causes us to put all our resources, thoughts and energy into meeting that need. the motivation to survive is inate, we dont have to learn it, we dont even have to think about it.
 
 why exactly do we desire so strongly to survive? why are we so designed to reflexively stay alive? this goes beyond regular motivation, this isnt something we can think ourselves out of.
 
 what are some other good resources that discusses this question?

 As I said, the exact mechanic will likely remain unknown, since it would not have left any traces. Just like you can\'t know whether there was a large hydrogen fire in the air in the past, since all that it would have left is water in the atmosphere.
 
 We try to piece the actual process together by following the evolution backwards, and unfortunately, the further back we go, the fewer traces we have.
 
 A fossil of a large bone is one thing to find, but the fossil of a proto bacterium? Unlikely.
 
 Alternatively, we could try to recreate the conditions and see where processes start. If we see how self sustaining processes start, we could figure out which ones may have become us.
 
 
 And before you start: this is what actual evidence points at and has a LOOOOOOT more going for it than a certain book written a few thousand years back by bronze age tribes. At least science can say "we found this fossil, and it points to this, and that fossil points to that, and we think this is how they came to be".
